metadata.case_name: Vishwabharti Insurance Company & Ors. v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Vishwabharti Insurance Company was a composite insurer carrying on life insurance business and other classes of insurance business.

LIC Act came into force on July 1, 1956; Corporation established on September 1, 1956, the appointed day under s.2(1). On that day, under s.7, all assets and liabilities appertaining to life insurance business (controlled business) transferred to and vested in Corporation.

By resolution dated December 18, 1948, Rs. 1,10,000/- transferred from General Department to Life Department as advance to Life Department Revenue Account for addition to Life Fund, no interest, no repayment except out of valuation surplus.

First actuarial valuation report for 1944-48 dated July 18, 1949: net liability Rs. 6,55,718/-, Life Fund Rs. 6,57,450/-, surplus Rs. 1,732/-. Without transfer, net liability would exceed Life Fund by about Rs. 1 lakh.
Profit & Loss Appropriation Account 1949: Rs. 60,000/- out of Rs. 1,10,000/- written off as company had made profits.

By resolution dated August 20, 1953, Rs. 32,000/- transferred from General to Life Fund with retrospective effect from December 31, 1952, no interest, repayment only out of future valuation surplus or written off from future profits of General Department.
Second actuarial valuation 1949-52 dated September 9, 1953: policy liability Rs. 15,33,068/-, Life Fund Rs. 15,35,890/-, surplus Rs. 2,822/- due to Rs. 32,000/- transfer.

By resolution dated January 6, 1956, confirmed February 6, 1956: Rs. 82,000/- (Rs. 50,000 + Rs. 32,000) transferred from Life Fund to General Department as repayment of loan; balance Rs. 60,000/- kept in reserve.
Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance, 1956 promulgated January 19, 1956; prohibited transfers from controlled business assets without approval.

Actuary letter dated July 25, 1955: policy liability Rs. 20,20,421/-, Life Fund Rs. 21,32,455/-, surplus Rs. 1,12,033/- including Rs. 53,300/- appreciation; net working surplus Rs. 58,733/-; sufficient for bonus Rs. 48,000/-.
Corporation applied to Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur under s.15 LIC Act in Case No. 30/XII of 1959 for Rs. 82,000/- + interest from Sept 1, 1956 against company and directors including appellants.

Tribunal judgment and order dated February 27, 1960: decreed Rs. 82,000/- + 6% interest from Sept 1, 1956 jointly and severally against company and directors 1-4; held transfers not loans, not from valuation surplus, not prudent.
Company ordered to be wound up by Bombay High Court on November 9, 1959.
Appellants: Damji Valji Shah, Jayantilal Hirijibhai Chawda (CA 676/62), Ghanshyamdas (CA 677/62) parties to resolutions.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal had jurisdiction to proceed without leave of High Court under s.446 Companies Act, 1956 after winding-up order dated Nov 9, 1959.
Whether s.44(a) LIC Act barred applicability of LIC Act provisions to company under winding-up, affecting Tribunal jurisdiction.
Whether transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from Life Fund to General Department was for consideration (repayment of loan from surplus), reasonably necessary/prudent for controlled business under s.15 LIC Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from Life Fund to General Department under resolution Jan 6, 1956 illegal, contrary to Insurance Act, inoperative; without consideration, not reasonably necessary for controlled business or made with unreasonable lack of prudence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.15 LIC Act; s.10 Insurance Act 1938

respondent_arguments.text: No jurisdiction without leave of Bombay High Court under s.446 Companies Act post winding-up; s.44(a) LIC Act bars proceedings; transfer was repayment of loan Rs. 82,000/- advanced to Life Dept from surplus per actuary report July 25, 1955.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.446 Companies Act 1956; s.44 LIC Act; s.15(1)(f) LIC Act

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction under s.41 LIC Act; s.446 Companies Act does not apply to Tribunal proceedings; special Act (LIC) overrides general (Companies); s.44(a) inapplicable as company not under winding-up when LIC Act applied (1956), and not 'insurer' post-takeover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Company Court has no jurisdiction over Tribunal matters; proceedings continue.

court_reasoning.text: Transfers of Rs.1,10,000 (1948) and Rs.32,000 (1952) not loans but augmentations/deposits to Life Fund to meet net liabilities; no ordinary inter-department loans; written off portions, no interest, repayable only from valuation surplus; 1956 transfer not from proper actuarial valuation surplus under s.13 Insurance Act (no Form I abstract); actuary letter 1955 not formal valuation, net surplus Rs.58,733 < Rs.82,000; transfer anticipatory of nationalisation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount continued as part of life insurance assets vesting in Corporation under s.7 LIC Act.

holdings.text: Tribunal had jurisdiction; s.446 and s.44(a) do not bar proceedings.
Transfers to Life Fund not loans; Rs.82,000/- transfer invalid, without consideration, not prudent; vests in Corporation recoverable from company/directors.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 (Act XXXI of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer/vesting of controlled business; Tribunal application for invalid transfers; exclusive jurisdiction; inapplicable to wound-up insurers at commencement.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938 (Act IV of 1938)
statutes_cited.relevance: Separate Life Fund maintenance; deposits for life business; actuarial valuations/surplus; prohibitions on use.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Leave required for proceedings post-winding-up; does not apply to Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance, 1956 (Ord. No.1 of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibited transfers from controlled business assets pre-LIC Act.

outcome.summary: Appeals by special leave against Tribunal decree dismissed; Tribunal correctly held Rs.82,000/- transfer invalid, recoverable with 6% interest from Sept 1, 1956 jointly/severally from company and directors; jurisdiction upheld.
outcome.relief_granted: Upheld Tribunal decree for Rs.82,000/- + interest

key_quotes.text: "No question of lending money by one department of the company to the other can be ordinarily contemplated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects loan characterization of inter-department transfers.

key_quotes.text: "The provisions of the special Act i.e., the LIC Act, will over-ride the provisions of the general Act viz., the Companies Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms Tribunal jurisdiction over Companies Act restrictions.

key_quotes.text: "It was out of such surplus that the company resolved that the advances... could be paid to the General Department... No such actuarial valuation was made... prior to the transfer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Invalidates 1956 transfer lacking proper valuation surplus.
